conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same velocity at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze the given graph, which shows the relationship between acceleration and time for both objects.
The graph shows acceleration \( a \) on the y-axis and time \( t \) on the x-axis.
The line represents the acceleration of both objects over time.
The slope of the line indicates the rate of change of acceleration with respect to time.
The graph shows a straight line, indicating constant acceleration for both objects.

premise: The slope of the line is positive.

conclusion: The acceleration \( a \) is constant over time.
Velocity \( v \) is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
For constant acceleration \( a \), the velocity \( v \) at time \( t \) is given by \( v = at \).

premise: For object A at time \( t_1 \), \( v_A = a \cdot t_1 \).
conclusion: Velocity of object A at time \( t_1 \) is \( a \cdot t_1 \).

premise: For object B at time \( t_1 \), \( v_B = a \cdot t_1 \).
conclusion: Velocity of object B at time \( t_1 \) is \( a \cdot t_1 \).

premise: Both objects have the same constant acceleration \( a \) and start from rest.
conclusion: Their velocities at any given time \( t \) will be the same.

premise: Conclusion that velocities are the same at time \( t_1 \).
conclusion: Yes, at time \( t_1 \), the two objects have the same velocity.
